[16. The physical sign of a person who is engaged in Rājayoga]
[XVI. The physical sign of a person who is engaged in Rājayoga] \phantomsection Now, the physical sign of a person who is engaged in Rājayoga is taught.The shift from Lakṣyayoga to the bodily sign of Rājayoga seems abrupt, but Rāmacandra follows the Yogasvarodaya's structure, treating the remaining Lakṣyayogas later.He is rich at all times.In light of Rāmacandra's understanding of Rājayoga as the ``yoga for kings,'' this translation for pūrṇa is obvious.He exists detached from the world [yet] having permeated the world.Cf. sarvangayoga 3.22: icchā parai tahāṃ so jāī | tīni loka mahiṃ aṭaka na kāī | svarga jāī devani mahiṃ baiṭhai | nāgaloka pātāla su paiṭhai || 22 ||For whom neither birth nor death exists;Cf. sarvangayoga 3.19d: jarā na vyāpai kāla na ṣāī | and 3.20c: ajara amara ati bajra śarīrā |happiness does not exist; suffering does not exist;Equanimity towards opposites in the state of Rājayoga are common among texts that teach Rājayoga, cf. e.g. amanaskaed 1.26ab: sukhaṃ duḥkhaṃ na jānāti śītoṣṇaṃ ca na vindati |; hp 4.111 ≈ nadabindu 53ab−54cd: na vijānāti śītoṣṇaṃ na duḥkhaṃ na sukhaṃ tathā | na mānaṃ nopamānaṃ ca yogī yuktaḥ samādhinā ||; also cf. sarvangayoga 3.18cd: jākaiṃ dukha aru sukha nahiṃ hoī | harṣa śoka vyāpai nahiṃ koī |lineage does not exist; moral conduct does not exist;Cf. datta2015 162.[and] abode does not exist in the mind of this accomplished [puruṣa], a light that is connected to God becomes perceptible. And, the light is not cold, not hot, neither white nor yellow.Cf. amanaskaed 1.51: vāsarārdhalayenāpi svātmajyotiḥ prakāśate | sūryo gobhir ivoddīpto yogī viśvaṃ prakāśate |; also cf. sarvangayoga 3.13cd: rājayoga saba ūpara chājai | jo sādhai so adhika birājai ||; and cf. sarvangayoga 3.23cd: hṛdai prakāśa rahai dina rātī | deśai jyoti tela bina vātī ||Neither does he have a caste, nor does he have any sign. Furthermore, he is without parts, immaculate and uncharacterized. And then, whatever wish for the most excellent fruit, affectionate woman, etc. arises,This statement is unusual as it contradicts standard renunciatory principles. For this reason, bhavati was changed to na bhavati in the transmission of the \gamma group. The passage is supported by the Yogasvarodaya: \ldots mahājyotir vāñchāṃ bhogaṃ dadāti ca | cf. sources. This suits the agenda of Rāmacandra of detaching Rājayoga from its renunciate connotations.he obtains that very enjoyment.For similar constructions to ``yasya yasyecchā \ldots taṃ taṃ bhogaṃ \ldots '' cf. anandakanda 1,15.312 and hathatattvakaumudi 5.39.However, his very mind does not experience attachment in this situation.Nearly all manuscripts omit (some even repeat) sentences at this section, likely due to eye skipping caused by structural similarity and brevity of the sentences.
